title: An Open-label Extension Study to Evaluate the Long-term Safety and Tolerability of Idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) as Adjunctive Treatment to Donepezil in Patients With Mild-moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: To evaluate the long-term safety and tolerability of idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) as adjunctive therapy to donepezil in patients with mild-moderate Alzheimer's Disease (AD).
description_detailed:
This is an interventional, multi-national, multi-site, open-label extension study in patients with mild to moderate AD who completed the 24-week lead-in study 14861A (NCT01955161) or 14862A (NCT02006641).

Patients received 28-weeks of open-label treatment with idalopirdine 60 mg/day (option to reduce to 30 mg/day) as adjunctive treatment to donepezil. Approximately 100 patients, who had completed the initial 28-week period (OLEX), were included in a 24 week open-label treatment period with memantine (OLEX-MEM) that evaluated the safety and tolerability of concomitant memantine therapy in patients who were already on a stable treatment with idalopirdine and donepezil and for whom memantine treatment was clinically indicated.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Open-label extension study in patients with mild to moderate AD who completed the 24-week lead-in study 14861A (NCT01955161) or 14862A (NCT02006641)

groups.title: Idalopirdine 60 mg
groups.description: Idalopirdine 60 mg adjunct to 10 mg donepezil. The dose of idalopirdine could be decreased from 60 mg to 30 mg if 60 mg was not well tolerated. The dose of donepezil was to be maintained throughout the study.

groups.title: Idalopirdine 60 mg + Memantine
groups.description: Idalopirdine 60 mg as adjunct to 10 mg donepezil and memantine (patient's individualised maintenance dose, either immediate-release (IR) 20 mg/day (recommended target dose) or extended release (XR) 28 mg/day (recommended target dose). Memantine was administered to approximately 100 patients included in the OLEX-MEM. The dose of idalopirdine could be decreased from 60 mg to 30 mg if 60 mg was not well tolerated. The dose of donepezil was to be maintained throughout the study. The dose of memantine could be changed at any time throughout the study.

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: A total of 1463 patients were enrolled into the study but 1 patient was not treated (did not receive IMP). The baseline analysis population only consist of patients who have been treated. The baseline measures are those collected at entry into the lead-in studies (Baseline I).

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Treatment Emergent Adverse Events (TEAEs) in the OLEX
outcomeMeasures.description: A TEAE is an adverse event that starts or increases in intensity after the date of Baseline II.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of IMP in the OLEX.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline II (start of OLEX, week 0) to end of OLEX (week 28)

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of TEAEs in the OLEX-MEM
outcomeMeasures.description: A TEAE is an adverse event that starts or increases in intensity after the date of Baseline III (start of OLEX-MEM).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients who took at least one dose of IMP or memantine in the OLEX-MEM.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: From Baseline III (start of OLEX-MEM, Week 28) to end of OLEX-MEM (Week 52)

groups.title: Idalopirdine 60 mg + Memantine
groups.description: Idalopirdine 60 mg as adjunct to 10 mg donepezil and memantine (patient's individualised maintenance dose, either immediate-release (IR) 20 mg/day (recommended target dose) or extended release (XR) 28 mg/day (recommended target dose). Memantine was administered to approximately 100 patients included in the OLEX-MEM. The dose of idalopirdine could be decreased from 60 mg to 30 mg if 60 mg was not well tolerated. The dose of donepezil was to be maintained throughout the study. The dose of memantine could be changed at any time throughout the study.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Cognition
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from Baseline II to Week 28 in Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-cognitive subscale (ADAS-Cog) total score. The ADAS-cog is a 11-item neuropsychological test that assess the severity of cognitive impairment. The items determine the patient's orientation, memory, language, and praxis. Total score of the 11 items range from 0 to 70 (lower score indicates lower cognitive impairment).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients in who took at least one dose of IMP in the OLEX.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline II (start of OLEX, Week 0) to Week 28

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Global Impression Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Clinical Global Impression of Change (ADCS-CGIC) score at Week 28. The ADCS-CGIC is a semi-structured interview to assess clinically relevant changes in patients with AD. The items determine cognition, behavior, social and daily functioning. Severity at baseline is rated on a 7-point scale from 1 (normal, not ill at all) to 7 (among the most extremely ill patients). The clinically relevant change from baseline is rated on a 7-point scale from 1 (marked improvement) to 7 (marked worsening).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients in who took at least one dose of IMP in the OLEX.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Daily Functioning
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from Baseline II to Week 28 in Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living Inventory (ADCS-ADL23) total score. The ADCS-ADL23 is a 23-item clinician-rated inventory to assess activities of daily living (conducted with a caregiver or informant). Each item comprises a series of hierarchical sub-questions, ranging from the highest level of independent performance to a complete loss for each activity. Total score of the 23 items ranges from 0 to 78 (higher score indicates lower disability).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients in who took at least one dose of IMP in the OLEX.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline II (start of OLEX, Week 0) to Week 28

Patients from lead-in Study 14682A

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Behavioural Disturbance
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from Baseline II to Week 28 in Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) total score. The NPI is a 12-item structured interview with a caregiver to assess behavioural disturbances. The NPI comprises 10 behavioural and 2 neurovegetative items. Each item consists of a screening question and several sub-questions that are rated no (not present) or yes (present). Each item is rated for frequency (a 4-point scale from 1 \[occasionally\] to 4 \[very frequent\]) and severity (a 3-point scale from 1 \[mild\] to 3 \[marked\]). The total NPI score is the frequency ratings multiplied by the severity ratings and ranges from 0 to 144 (higher score indicates worse outcome).
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients in who took at least one dose of IMP in the OLEX.
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Baseline II (start of OLEX, Week 0) to Week 28

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Cognitive Aspects of Mental Function
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from Baseline II to Week 28 in Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE). The MMSE is an 11-item test to assess the cognitive aspects of mental function. The subtests assess orientation, memory, attention, language, and visual construction. The scores for each item is dichotomous (1 = response is correct, 0 = response is incorrect). Total score of the 11 items ranges from 0 to 30 (higher score indicates lower deficit).

explanation_target: Reason: The trial description is an open-label extension evaluating idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) given adjunctively with donepezil to improve cognitive function/safety in mild–moderate Alzheimer’s disease. Idalopirdine is not a biologic and does not target amyloid or tau pathology; instead it is a small‑molecule antagonist of the serotonin 5‑HT6 receptor, a target pursued to enhance cognition. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Act (evidence / trial details): The study is NCT02079246 (open‑label extension) assessing long‑term safety/tolerability of idalopirdine 60 mg as adjunct to donepezil in mild–moderate AD. The investigational drug idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) has been studied for cognitive effects (e.g., LADDER phase 2) and shown pharmacology consistent with 5‑HT6 antagonism and cognitive enhancement when given with AChE inhibitors. The drug also potentiates some effects of donepezil in preclinical work. citeturn0search0turn0search5turn0search3turn0search4

Reflect: Classification — cognitive enhancer. Because idalopirdine is a small‑molecule 5‑HT6 receptor antagonist developed to improve cognitive performance (used adjunctively with donepezil) and does not directly target core AD pathology (amyloid/tau) or primarily treat neuropsychiatric symptoms, the correct category is 'cognitive enhancer'. This conclusion aligns with the cited pharmacology and clinical trial aims. citeturn0search2turn0search3
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug idalopirdine (Lu AE58054) is a small‑molecule antagonist of the serotonin 5‑HT6 receptor (a neurotransmitter receptor), developed as a cognitive enhancer given adjunctively with donepezil. This mechanism does not target core AD proteinopathies (amyloid or tau) but modulates neurotransmitter systems to improve cognition. citeturn0search1turn0search2

Act: Evidence from the trial registry and publications shows the open‑label extension NCT02079246 evaluated long‑term safety/tolerability of idalopirdine 60 mg/day as adjunct to donepezil in mild–moderate AD. Idalopirdine is repeatedly described as a selective 5‑HT6 receptor antagonist that can potentiate some effects of donepezil in preclinical models. citeturn1search0turn0search2

Reflect: The most specific CADRO fit is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors because the therapeutic target is a serotonin receptor (5‑HT6). Although donepezil (background therapy) acts on the cholinergic system, both agents act by modulating neurotransmitter systems rather than on amyloid, tau, inflammation, or other CADRO domains, so 'Neurotransmitter Receptors' is the correct category rather than Multi‑target or Other. citeturn0search6turn1search5
